page.title: 05FARGO PLANTATION, STONEHENGE
page.content: This plantation is owned by the National Trust and has not been ploughed since 1830. The first planting of trees took place in 1953. Prior to this it was natural woodland. It now contains a mixture of conifers, beech and some self set sycamores, and shelters such creatures as roe-deer, hares and pheasants. The conifers, which are in the minority, will be felled when they reach maturity leaving the beech to grow large. Some damage was done to trees by pop festival visitors and in 1983/84 the National Trust cleared the trees from the round barrows to prevent further damage by roots. They also cleared trees from the end of the Cursus, which intersects the plantation, more clearing may be done in the future depending on where the proposed Study Centre for Stonehenge is situated.
